Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Do lianas alter carbon, nutrient, and water dynamics in tropical forests? A large-scale experimental test
Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the most notable recent changes in tropical forests is the increase in woody vine (liana) abundance and biomass. This change is important because recent evidence suggests that lianas are major contributors to ecosystem processes and tree community coexistence. Increasing lianas will likely reduce tree growth, increase tree mortality, and change soil nutrient dynamics - thus changing tropical forest carbon, water, and nutrient fluxes. Lianas also may impede growth and regeneration of tree species with high wood density more than species with lower wood density, which would further reduce forest carbon stocks and fluxes. In the Republic of Panama, PIs will establish long-term experimental forest plots in which they remove lianas from half of the plots. The PIs will measure long-term changes in carbon dynamics, soil nutrient and water availability, and tree responses to lianas.

The proposed project will be the first large-scale, long-term experimental study to quantify the role of lianas in both community- and ecosystem-level processes, and it will provide a benchmark for predicting future tropical forest changes with changing liana abundance. The project will facilitate a variety of broader impacts, including international capacity building, student mentoring, and field-based education. The PIs will actively mentor post-docs and graduate and undergraduate students from the US and Latin America, as well as use the established experimental infrastructure for US-based study-abroad programs. The project also provides experimental infrastructure for additional collaborative research on tropical forest ecology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tropical forests store vast quantities of carbon, account for one-third of the carbon fixed by photosynthesis, and are a major sink in the global carbon cycle. When carbon is locked-up in tropical forests, it is not in the atmosphere where it contributes to global warming. Lianas (woody vines) were once thought to play a negligible role in forest carbon dynamics because their stems have relatively little biomass compared to trees - even in tropical forests, where lianas are particularly abundant. Our study, however, debunks this notion by demonstrating experimentally that lianas severely reduce forest-wide net carbon uptake by 76% per year, as well as shift net primary productivity to leaves at the expense of wood, thus decreasing overall carbon residence time. This NSF-funded project has resulted in the first series of studies to demonstrate experimentally and unequivocally the important contribution of lianas to tropical forest carbon budgets. Furthermore, this project allowed us to complete an additional series of projects that show that lianas have a wide range of negative effects on tree performance and regeneration. Lianas are increasing in abundance and biomass throughout the neotropics, and thus our findings have even greater relevance in terms of the fate of the carbon balance of tropical forests, as well as for atmospheric CO2 levels and associated climate change.  

 

We believe that this project will fundamentally change the way that scientists view carbon dynamics in tropical forests. The ability of lianas to reduce the capacity of tropical forests to store and sequester carbon also has consequences for a broad range of conservation projects, particularly those focused on enhancing carbon capture by tropical forests (e.g. LULUCF and REDD+ initiatives under the Paris climate protocol). Our results indicate that the presence of lianas must be considered when deciding on management protocols and are therefore of crucial importance to policy makers, conservationists and forestry professionals.

 

Broader impacts from this project include the training of a large number of graduate and undergraduate students. By establishing a large-scale experimental infrastructure, this project provided a wide variety of opportunities for students to conduct directed studies within the larger experimental framework. To that end, we have published a series of papers with both graduate and undergraduates, who gained valuable research experience while working on this project. In addition to student training, this project allowed us to work with and mentor more than a dozen students and field technicians from the Republic of Panama, where the study was conducted.
